#### Section 1: Introduction
Organic molecules comprise 99% of what we mean when we say "molecules."
The ability to speak a few words of Organic---as in a language---is thus
profoundly valuable when engineering organic nanostructures. One type of
organic nanostructure is a **polymer**. Polymers are long chains of
atoms, usually made of carbon and a few other elements. This is the
first chapter in a series of three on polymers. Chapter 5 treats
polymers as examples of organic nanostructures (as in vaccine delivery
particles), Chapter 6 treats them as the components of solid objects (as
in a piece of plexiglass), and Chapter 7 covers some examples of
electronic polymers. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/v_5SYuuiyK4)

Organic structures play a central role in nanoengineering. They comprise
all polymers (including all photoresists used in nanofabrication),
liquid crystals, molecular dyes, and many of the additives used during
the growth of nanocrystals and quantum dots. Moreover, polymers are
found widely in biology and comprise most biological macromolecules:
polypeptides, polysaccharides, and nucleic acids. Almost every drug
molecule is an organic structure. Lucky for us, it is not necessary to
take an entire year of organic chemistry to learn what you need to know
to be an effective nanoengineer. In fact, it's best not to even think of
this material as "organic chemistry." Rather, you can think of it as
*molecular structure and bonding*. It just so happens that most
molecules are made of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen and a few other
supporting players like sulfur and phosphorous, and thus considered
"organic."

the growth of nanocrystals and quantum dots. Moreover, polymers are
found widely in biology and comprise most biological macromolecules:
polypeptides, polysaccharides, and nucleic acids. Almost every drug
molecule is an organic structure. Lucky for us, it is not necessary to
take an entire year of organic chemistry to learn what you need to know
to be an effective nanoengineer. In fact, it's best not to even think of
this material as "organic chemistry." Rather, you can think of it as

supporting players like sulfur and phosphorous, and thus considered

#### Section 2: Basic nomenclature
Just like writing in a markup language like LaTeX or HTML, one can
describe any molecule using a linear sequence of words, numbers, and
brackets. We will call this language *Organic*. It operates by the
nomenclature established by the International Union of Pure and Applied
Chemistry (IUPAC). However, by describing chemical structures only in
words, the IUPAC name gets really long even for simple compounds. In
fact, most chemists don't use IUPAC names for any but the most basic
structures (e.g., methane, ethane, propane, and butane). After all, it
is almost always easier to just draw the structure. Moreover, most
complicated structures have common names (like aspirin, ibuprofen, and
Paxlovid). Thankfully, we don't need to know very many types of
structures in this course. Let's start with the linear hydrocarbons.

### 5.2.1. Hydrocarbons: Counting to twelve in *Organic* Just like any
other language, Organic has words corresponding to numbers of carbon
atoms. So, the words for the hydrocarbons of the general formula C
$_{{n}}$ H $_{2{n}+2}$ as follows for $n$:

1.  methane

2.  ethane

3.  propane

4.  butane

5.  pentane

6.  hexane

7.  heptane

8.  octane

9.  nonane

10. decane

11. undecane

12. dodecane

If you need to count beyond 12, there is a pattern: tridecane,
tetradecane, pentadecane, hexadecane, heptadecane, octadecane,
nonadecane, and finally isocane for $n=20$.

When converting the name of molecule to its structure, we usually leave
out the carbon and hydrogen atoms. The reason is because they appear so
regularly it would be tedious if we had to keep writing them. Instead,
we just draw the bonds---the atoms are implied. A carbon atom always has
four bonds. If the bonding partners are not shown, we assume that the
remaining bonds are to hydrogen. Every vertex and terminus of the
structure signify a carbon atom. So, pentane, with the empirical formula
C $_{5}$ H $_{12}$ , has the structure shown in Figure (5.1):

(Figure 5.1) 
>>>image(pentane.png.0)

Verify that you could draw the structures of any of the hydrocarbons
with $n=1-20$.

#### Section 3: Functional groups
Molecules with carbon-containing backbones are called **organic
molecules**. The most common elements beside carbon and hydrogen
incorporated into organic molecules that occur naturally are oxygen and
nitrogen, and to a lesser extent, phosphorous (e.g., found in the
backbone of DNA) and sulfur (e.g., found in the amino acids cysteine and
methionine). Unnatural organic structures can contain many other
elements, such as chlorine (e.g., polyvinyl chloride) or bromine.

The site where non-carbon elements are incorporated into an organic
molecule is called a **functional group**. These groups are called
*functional* because they often dictate the properties---thermodynamic
properties like melting and boiling point, along with chemical
properties like reactivity---of the molecule. It is not uncommon for
molecules to have many functional groups. The most common functional
groups you will encounter are shown in Figure (5.2), below.

(Figure 5.2) 
>>>image(functional groups.png.0)

R represents any group or part of a molecule, with the expectation that
the first atom of the R group is carbon. The C=O (double bond) subunit
of acids, amides, and esters is called a **carbonyl**. All of the
functional groups in this list are polar---capable of bonding by
dipole-dipole and dipole-induced dipole forces---and alcohols, amines,
carboxylic acids, and amides are donors of hydrogen bonds. All five
structures are also capable of accepting hydrogen bonds through the lone
pairs on the oxygen atom of the carbonyl, or through the nitrogen atom
(for amines).

#### Section 4: Chemical reactivity
In this course, we have taken a relaxed definition of the word "bond"
such that it includes van der Waals bonds and other electrostatic
interactions. In this section, we will briefly mention the types of
bonds that form in traditional chemical systems. That is, those that
involve the movement or formal sharing or transfer of electrons.

### 5.4.1. Electrostatic attraction and ionic bonding The most basic
type of bond is the one described in subsection (2.1.1). This is a
classic ionic bond between oppositely charged species that obeys
Coulomb's law of electrostatic attraction. There is no formal sharing of
electrons; they simply attract and get stuck to each other because
that's what objects with opposite charges do. The quintessential example
is the "bonding" of a sodium ion and a chloride ion to get
Na$^{+}+$Cl$^-$=NaCl. In some cases, such an interaction arises because
of a formal **electron transfer** reaction. For example, if a neutral
sodium atom (Na$^0$) came in close proximity to a neutral chlorine atom
(Cl$^0$), then an electron would jump from the sodium atom to the
chlorine atom. The sodium atom would be oxidized to Na$^+$ and the
chlorine atom would be reduced to Cl$^-$. Once formally charged in this
way, the ions would interact electrostatically.[^5.4.1]

### 5.4.2. Reactivity arising from functional groups Functional groups
react with one another by moving electrons around to form new covalent
bonds. In the zig-zag drawings, each bond represents a pair of
electrons. In covalent bonds like C-H, C-C, or C-F, one electron comes
from one atom of the bonded pair, and one electron comes from the
other.[^5.4.2] Chemical reactions are **quantum mechanical**, meaning that
the electrons occupy an **orbital** whose shape and energy level are
predicted by solutions to the Schrödinger equation or more complicated
mathematical techniques.[^5.4.3] Regardless of these complexities, the
movement of electrons can often be predicted by electrostatics. That is,
atoms bearing partial negative charges are drawn to atoms bearing
partial positive charges. A partial charge is generated any time two
atoms with unequal electronegativities are bonded to each other. In this
case, the electrons attached to the atom with the partial negative
charge---the **nucleophile**---move to bond with the atom with the
partial positive charge---the **electrophile**---to form a bond. In
Figure (5.3), below, the oxygen atom attacks the carbon atom at a
polarized C--Br bond to form an **ether bond**.

(Figure 5.3) 
>>>image(sn2.png.0)

While we often associate functional groups with the presence of
**heteroatoms**---atoms other than carbon or hydrogen---it turns out
that double and triple bonds between carbon atoms are also reactive to
form new bonds. This reactivity arises from the properties of $\pi$
bonds, which run parallel (but separated from) the $\sigma$ bond that
defines the internuclear axis (i.e., the line connecting the elements).
Such functional groups based on double and triple bonds are particularly
important for applications in nanoengineering. For example, polymers and
polymeric nanoparticles are produced by the reaction of double bonds to
form polymers, as shown in Figure (5.4), below.

(Figure 5.4) 
>>>image(polymerization.png.0)

Additionally, triple bonds (called **alkynes**) and azides (--N $_{3}$ )
form a linkage called a triazole in a copper-catalyzed reaction called a
Huisgen cycloaddition,[^5.4.4] meaning that the reaction forms a ring. This
reaction is so sure-fire, quick, and irreversible, it is one of the most
famous examples of a transformation called a **click reaction**, Figure
(5.5). This process has been used to bind proteins and drugs to
nanoparticles, nanoparticles to each other, and molecules to surfaces.
The azide-alkyne cycloaddition is not the only click reaction, but it is
the most famous, and usually the one people are talking about.

(Figure 5.5) 
>>>image(click.png.0)

If you have taken a class in organic chemistry, you probably encountered
curly arrows or "arrow-pushing mechanisms." That is, the way organic
chemists account for the movement of all of the electrons in a reaction.
In this class---and in many applications in nanoengineering---it is more
useful to think of functional groups as Lego blocks or Tetris pieces.
That is, they fit only with specific reaction partners. Just know that
electrons are never created nor destroyed in these processes, and people
actually do know how to account for all the electrons.

It is also useful to remember a few things to avoid the most common
errors when considering the products of chemical reactions. Among them:

1.  Carbon usually has four bonds, never five

2.  Oxygen has two bonds; if it has three, it gets a positive charge,
    and if it has one, it gets a negative charge

3.  Nitrogen has three bonds; if it has four, then it gets a positive
    charge

[^5.4.1]: Prior to the transfer of the electron, the neutral atoms would
    interact by London dispersion. The transfer of the electron followed
    by strong interaction by ionic bonding is called the **harpoon
    effect**.

[^5.4.2]: Recall the octet rule from high school chemistry.

[^5.4.3]: More on the Schrödinger equation to come in Chapter 8!

[^5.4.4]: You *definitely* don't need to know this name.

#### Section 5: Polymers as molecules and nanostructures
Polymeric materials are ubiquitous in nanoengineering applications. For
example, as **photoresists** (the light-sensitive chemicals used in
microelectronics fabrication), as **drug-delivery nanoparticles**, as
**biomaterials** for regenerative medicine, as the charge-transport or
encapsulation layers in **thin-film photovoltaic cells**, and as
components of **nanocomposite aerospace materials**. Compared to
inorganic solids, polymers offer greater mechanical strength and
toughness, light weight, and synthetic tunability for biocompatibility,
light emission and absorption, chemical sensitivity, mechanical
compliance, and many other useful attributes.

There are two ways in which we can consider the properties of polymers.
The first way---discussed in this chapter---treats polymers as chemical
objects. That is, molecules or nanomaterials having properties like
dipole moment, molecular weight, and polarizability. The second
way---discussed in the next chapter---treats polymers as solid materials
having bulk properties. That is, density, modulus, and conductivity.

### 5.5.1. Structure of polymers

Exemplars of polymer synthesis are shown in Figure (5.4). Polymers are
named after the monomer, whether or not something that looks like the
monomer is actually incorporated into the backbone of the polymer. For
example, in the synthesis of polyethylene, the monomer ethylene contains
a double bond, whereas the bonds in polyethylene are all single bonds.
The double bond in the monomer is needed because the electrons involved
in the $\pi$ bond of the double bond are needed to form the new single
bond between monomers. Technically, the monomers are called **monomer
residues** once incorporated into the backbone of a polymer, though this
word is used mostly by biologists in reference to **amino acid
residues** that make up the linear structure of proteins.

#### Polyolefins

The polymers polyethylene and poly(methylmethacrylate) shown in Figure
(5.4) are called **polyolefins**, which means that they are derived from
the rearrangement of the $\pi$ bonds of double bonded monomers to form
the polymer.[^5.5.1] A characteristic of such polymers is that the backbone
*contains nothing but carbon atoms!* Most polymers that look like this
are made industrially by a **radical, cationic**, or **anionic
mechanism**, we will not go through these mechanisms in detail. Suffice
it to say, radical mechanisms operate by splitting the $\pi$ bond of the
monomer into two individual electrons, which link up to form the new
bonds. Cationic polymerizations are mediated by the movement of a
positive charge, and anionic polymerizations are mediated by the
movement of a negative charge.

#### Polycondensation reactions

There are other polymers, however, which contain *heteroatoms* in the
backbone, such as oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur, and silicon. Some of the
most well known examples of these heteroatom-containing polymers are
derived from carbonyl compounds, and form polymer with the carbonyls
intact. Examples of nitrogen-containing polymers that follow this
pattern are nylon and Kevlar (Figure (5.6), below).

(Figure 5.6) 
>>>image(polyamide.png.0)

Examples of oxygen-containing polymers that follow this pattern are
polycarbonate (used in eyeglasses) and poly(ethylene terephthalate)
(PET, a.k.a. polyester, used in clothing and soda bottles, Figure
(5.7)).

(Figure 5.7) 
>>>image(PET.png.0)

The chemical process by which such materials are synthesized is known as
**polycondensation**, Figure (5.8). A polycondensation reaction follows
the general formula, shown below. The key is that a small molecule
(often either water or hydrochloric acid) is ejected for every monomer
that joins the chain. The reaction is termed a *condensation* because
the molecular weight of the polymer chain is less than the weight of all
the monomers by the amount of this ejected monomer.

(Figure 5.8) 
>>>image(polycondensation.png.0)

[^5.5.1]: **Olefin** was the old-timey name for alkene, or carbon-carbon
    double bond. One might have said so in the first place!

#### Section 6: Polymerization kinetics: Chain-growth and step-growth
A polymer chain can grow one of two ways, by a **chain-growth** process
(a.k.a. **addition**) or by a **step-growth** process (a.k.a.
**condensation**). In chain-growth processes, one monomer adds one at a
time to the growing chain end: monomers react only with growing chain
ends. Monomers do not react with each other except upon **initiation**,
and polymer chains do not react with each other, except upon
**termination**. Chain-growth processes can be further subdivided into
**uncontrolled** or **controlled** reaction types. In step-growth
processes, every monomer and polymer is reactive toward every other
monomer and polymer in the mixture. The growth process of a polymer
determines its distribution of molecular weight and has a profound
influence on the applications to which it is suited.

### 5.6.1. Chain-growth: Uncontrolled

Of the 370 million metric tons ("tonnes") of polymers produced annually
around the globe, the vast majority are polyolefins, and around half of
these are synthesized by (uncontrolled) free-radical polymerization.
These materials are dominated by polyethylene (plastic bags and milk
jugs), polypropylene (carpet), poly(vinyl chloride) (pipes, shower
curtains, LP records), and polystyrene (styrofoam, plastic petri
dishes). We will not go into the mechanism here, but the reaction
proceeds by what I think of as the *popcorn mechanism*. Picture all the
monomers in a big steel reactor. A radical initiator is sprinkled in.
Each initiator molecule, at some random time, causes a chain reaction.
One monomer reacts with the next to form a dimer, the dimer reacts with
another monomer to form a trimer, the trimer reacts with another monomer
to form a tetramer. This process repeats hundreds or thousands of times
until it stops abruptly by colliding with another molecule. Some
polymers stop at 100 monomers, some stop at 500 or 10,000. The number of
monomer residues in a polymer chain is called the **degree of
polymerization**, $i$, and in free radical polymerizations it is a
statistical assortment of sort-of random chain lengths. This randomness
leads to a large distribution of degrees of polymerization or
**dispersity**.[^5.6.1]

Because of the randomness with which each polymer chain initiates and
speed with which it grows once commenced, the reaction mixture consists
of unreacted monomers, along with fully formed polymer chains, with very
few partly formed polymers. Thus, the average molecular weight, $M_{n}$,
of polymer chains---excluding unreacted monomers---is reached quickly. I
call uncontrolled chain growth the *popcorn mechanism* because at any
location, you have either a piece of popcorn---a polymer chain---or an
unpopped kernel---a monomer. The "pops" occur in random locations in the
reaction mixture. A conceptual drawing showing the wide range in
distribution of molecular weights is shown in the following, Figure
(5.9).

(Figure 5.9) 
>>>image(uncontrolled.png.0)

### 5.6.2. Chain-growth: Controlled or "living"

A controlled chain-growth process is one in which the polymerization is
slowed to an extent that all polymer chains initiate at around the same
time, and then monomers add a few at a time to each growing polymer
chain. Often, this type of process is called **living** (Figure (5.10)),
meaning that once one type of monomer is consumed, a second type of
monomer can be added into the reaction mixture, which then adds to the
growing polymer chains.

(Figure 5.10) 
>>>image(living.png.0)

#### Block copolymers

Thus, it is possible to make polymers with *blocks* of each type of
monomer residue. Such a structure is called a **block copolymer**.
Polymers with the structure AAAABBBBB etc. are called **diblock**
copolymers, and those of the type AAAABBBBCCCC are called **triblock**
copolymers. While most **homopolymers**[^5.6.2] phase separate when mixed
(like oil and water), block copolymers do not. In fact, while the "A"
blocks and the "B" blocks of block copolymers might "prefer" to be
separated, they are covalently linked and thus prevented from doing so.
Instead, they form nanostructures of "A domains" inside of a continuous
phase of B, or vice-versa.[^5.6.3] Typically, block copolymers give the
"best of both worlds" in properties held by either block alone. In
contrast, physical blends of the two polymers (without covalent
attachment) tends to give an averaging of the properties, which leads to
materials having the "worst of both worlds" (e.g., of, say, strength and
chemical resistance). Block copolymers are useful for many things, such
as porous films for separation membranes, low-dielectric films for
graphics processors, and as **thermoplastic elastomers**[^5.6.4] for 3D
printing, e.g., poly(styrene-butadiene-styrene), or SBS rubber.

### 5.6.3. Step-growth polymerization

In contrast to chain-growth polymerization, in which monomers add to
growing chains one at a time, in a step-growth process, anything goes.
That is, a monomer has two reactive ends and can react with any monomer
or any growing chain in the soup. So, a dimer can add to a dimer to make
a tetramer, two tetramers can add to form an octomer, and basically
anything in the mix an add to anything else at any time. As a result of
this process, it takes a long time (percentage of reacted functional
groups) for polymers to form with large molecular weights. That is, it's
not until the last few reactions that 50-mers form 100-mers, 100-mers
form 200-mers, and so on.[^5.6.5] For most of the reaction, you have mostly
short oligomers. At the end, you have long polymers. The rough plot of
$M_{n}$ vs. % reacted functional groups for step-growth polymerization
processes looks like the plot shown in Figure (5.11).

(Figure 5.11) 
>>>image(step-growth.png.0)

### 5.6.4. A word about molecular weight

The molecular weight of a polymer can be described in various ways, the
two most popular of which are the **number-average molecular weight**,
$M_{n}$, and the **weight-average molecular weight**, $M_{w}$. The
former, $M_{n}$, is the conventional average. To get $M_n$, we add up
the weight of the entire sample of polymer and divides by the number of
chains, as in equation (5.1):

(Equation 5.1) $$M_n=\frac{\Sigma N_i M_i}{\Sigma N_i}$$

where $N_i$ is the number of polymers with degree of polymerization $i$
and $M_i$ is the mass of the chain with degree of polymerization $i$.
This method of calculating the average molecular weight can be
misleading, however. This method of calculating the molecular weight
tends to over-value the contributions of low-molecular-weight chains in
the sample, even though most of the actual mass of the sample is made of
higher molecular weight stuff. For example, if a sample consisted of two
polymer chains, one with a mass of 20 and one with a mass of 2,000,000,
then $M_n$ would be about 1,000,000, but the properties would be
dominated by the chain which occupied the largest fraction of the
sample, by mass. In fact, it would behave almost identically to a sample
with $M_n$ of 2,000,000. To account for this misleading result of using
only the $M_n$ to characterize the sample, we use $M_w$. This value
gives you a number that reflects the weights of the polymer chains that
represent the largest fraction of the sample, as in equation (5.2)

(Equation 5.2)
$$M_w=\frac{\Sigma w_i M_i}{\Sigma w_i}=\frac{\Sigma N_i M_i^2}{\Sigma N_i M_i}$$

where $w_i$ is the weight of the entire sample with degree of
polymerization $i$, or $N_iM_i$. Molecular weight (any type) has the
units of g mol$^{-1}$ or Dalton, Da.

#### Dispersity

The dispersity is defined as =$\frac{M_w}{M_n}$, which is always
$\geq$ 1. The larger the number , the larger the distribution of
molecular weights. In general, as we will find in the next chapter,
larger s mean less internal order, lower **glass transition
temperatures**, and greater mechanical compliance.

### 5.6.5. Polymers as nanomaterials

Polymers are one of the most fundamental types of nanostructured
materials: a single polymer chain in solution is, fundamentally, a
nanoparticle. The characteristic size of a polymer chain in solution is
given by its **radius of gyration**, $R_g$, which can be thought of as
the average distance[^5.6.6] of the monomer residues from the center of mass
of the polymer blob, which approximates a sphere. The $R_g$ can
effectively be treated as a measure of the size of the polymer blob in
solution.

The volume of a polymer blob can be thought of in two different ways.
The first way is to calculate the volume taken up by the polymer blob,
including the solvent molecules, or $V=\frac{4}{3}\pi R_g^3$. The second
way is to calculate the volume of the polymer strand, which can be
visualized as a long cylinder, like a piece of spaghetti. This volume is
approximately 10% of the volume of the polymer blob, which means that
the total volume occupied by the blob is actually 90% solvent!

The size of the blob depends on the solvent. In a "good" solvent, which
has favorable interactions with the monomer residues of the polymer, the
blob expands. In a "bad" solvent, the monomer residues prefer
interacting with themselves (and/or the solvent molecules prefer
interacting with themselves instead of the polymer), and the blob
contracts. In the middle, we have a **theta solvent**, which is a
solvent that is good enough to "cancel out" the van der Waals forces
between the monomer residues, and the size of the polymer blob is
somewhere in between what it would be in a good solvent on one side and
a bad solvent on the other. You can think of a theta solvent as being
"invisible" to the polymer blob. That is, the polymer chain behaves as
if there were no van der Waals forces between the residues. Because the
entropy of a polymer in solution---and thus its solubility---depends on
temperature, any solvent can be turned into a theta solvent at a
specific temperature, known as the **theta temperature**.

### 5.6.6. Molecular weight determination

The molecular weight---either $M_n$ or $M_w$---is one of the most
important parameters which characterizes a polymer sample. It can be
determined in a number of ways, but rarely with complete accuracy. For
example, the viscosity of a polymer solution or melt increases with
increasing $M$ in a predictable way using **viscometry**. The most
common methods however use the the size of the polymers in solution as a
substitute for the molecular weight.

#### Size-exclusion chromatography

A versatile method for determining the molecular weight ($M_n$, $M_w$,
and thus ) is based on the retention time of polymers in solution as it
passes through a gel consisting of porous beads. In this method, the
larger polymer blobs go around the beads and **elute**[^5.6.7] first. The
smaller polymer blobs get temporarily stuck inside the pores within the
beads and come out later. This method is often referred to in polymer
engineering as **gel-permeation chromatography (GPC)**, but is perhaps
better described using a term for the same technique but which is used
in biochemistry, **size-exclusion chromatography (SEC)**.

### 5.6.7. Other characterization tools There are other
characterization tools used in the determination of the molecular weight
of polymers, including **dynamic light scattering** (DLS), which can be
used to measure the sizes of particles based on the rate at which they
get closer together and farther apart due to random Brownian motion.
Another technique is matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization
time-of-flight mass spectrometry (**MALDI-TOF-MS**). In MALDI-TOF-MS,
the polymer is coated on a thin polymeric matrix which is blasted with
charged particles. The matrix and the polymer of interest are fragmented
by the beam and accelerated toward a detector. The amount of time that
it takes to reach the detector is based on the ratio of mass to charge.
From these data, it is usually possible to determine the mass of the
largest fragment, which often corresponds to that of the entire polymer
chain. Finally, the sizes of polymer blobs can be obtained by
measurements of **osmotic pressure**. In this method, the pressure
generated through a semi-permeable membrane can be related to the size
and molecular weight of the polymer blobs.

[^5.6.1]: The dispersity used to be called the *polydispersity*, but then
    IUPAC decided this word was redundant.

[^5.6.2]: A retronym meaning "not a copolymer."

[^5.6.3]: A quick Google search for "block copolymer nanostructure" will
    show some of the intricate nanoscale patters that can be achieved.

[^5.6.4]: Rubber that can be melted and reformed

[^5.6.5]: I'm not sure who said this first, but I attribute it to Lieutenant
    Sulu on *Star Trek*: If you have a penny and double it every day for
    a month, you'll be poor for most of that month, but at the end of
    the month you'll be a millionaire.

[^5.6.6]: Technically the root-mean squared distance.

[^5.6.7]: come out

#### Section 7: Outlook
I used to co-teach a graduate seminar called *Organic Nanomaterials*
with a colleague who was polymer chemist. When figuring out how to divvy
up the course material, we decided that he would focus on the chemical
aspects of polymer science---"polymers as molecules"---and I would focus
on the fact that polymers are most often used as materials---"polymers
as materials." Indeed it is often possible to predict much about the
bulk properties of a polymeric solid by knowing some details about its
molecular structure.[^5.7.1] Once a polymeric structure is condensed into
the solid phase, it takes on properties associated with materials:
mechanical properties, surface energy, thermal transitions,
conductivity, actuation, and so forth. Moreover, most of the techniques
we have discussed for measuring the properties of polymers as
molecules---e.g., spectroscopy, light scattering, size-exclusion
chromatography, etc.---will not work on solids. We thus devote the next
chapter to the consideration of polymers as solids, and in particular
the nanoscale features that can be engineered to give such materials
their properties.

[^5.7.1]: This is the realm of the area of study known as
    **structure-property relationships**, in which systematic changes
    are made to a chemical structure for the purposes of understanding
    the effect on a property.
